hints_html:
For an improper integral of the form

\[\begin{aligned} \int_1^\infty f(x)\,dx\end{aligned}\]

to converge it is necessary (but not sufficient) that f(x) approaches 0 as x goes to infinity. Check this condition first to rule out some candidates that do not satisfy this.

For the remaining candidates try the integral test.

hints_raw:
For an improper integral of the form

:<math> \int_1^\infty f(x)\,dx </math>

to converge it is necessary (but not sufficient) that ''f(x)'' approaches 0 as ''x'' goes to infinity. Check this condition first to rule out some candidates that do not satisfy this.
For the remaining candidates try the integral test.
question: 1 (e)
sols_html:
Let’s check first the if the integrand goes to 0, as a necessary condition for convergence.

i. \(\lim_{x \rightarrow \infty} e^{3x} = \infty\)

ii. \(\lim_{x \rightarrow \infty} x^{-1} = 0 \checkmark\)

iii. \(\lim_{x \rightarrow \infty} x^{-1/2} = 0 \checkmark\)

iv. \(\lim_{x \rightarrow \infty} x^{-2} = 0 \checkmark\)

v. \(\lim_{x \rightarrow \infty} \frac{x^2}{1000} = \infty\)

This only leaves candidates ii., iii., and iv..

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \text{Since } x^{1/2} < x < x^2 \text{ we have } x^{-1/2} > x^{-1} > x^{-2} \text{ and thus }\end{aligned}\]

\[\begin{aligned} \int_{1}^{\infty} x^{-1/2}\,dx > \int_{1}^{\infty} x^{-1}\,dx > \int_{1}^{\infty}x^{-2}\,dx\end{aligned}\]

Since we are told that only one of the five integrals converges it must be iv.. (E.g., if the integral of ii. was finite, and the integral in iv. is less than the integral in ii., then iv. would also necessarily be finite.)

And indeed, iv. does converge: By the integral test,

\[\begin{aligned} \int_{1}^{\infty}x^{-2} \, dx\end{aligned}\]

converges if

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}n^{-2}\end{aligned}\]

converges. This sum does converge by the p-series test. Hence the correct answer is iv..

As a fun fact,

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}n^{-2} = \frac{\pi^{2}}{6}\end{aligned}\]

statement_html:
Multiple Choice Question: Exactly ONE of the answers provided is correct. There is no partial credit in this questions.

Which of the following improper integrals converges?

i. \(I = \int_1^\infty e^{3x}\,dx\)

ii. \(I = 10^{-5} \int_1^\infty x^{-1}\,dx\)

iii. \(I = \int_1^\infty x^{-1/2}\,dx\)

iv. \(I = \int_1^\infty x^{-2}\,dx\)

v. \(I = \int_1^\infty \frac{x^2}{1000}\,dx\)
